mods.abstract: President Lyndon B. Johnson's visit to Nashville. Shows view of log cabin located on the grounds of The Hermitage, home of Andrew Jackson.

The Hermitage was the home of Andrew Jackson. It was built in 1819 and enlarged in 1831. It is a Greek Revival mansion located in Davidson County, Tennessee, outside of Nashville. Today, the house and grounds are a popular tourist attraction for visitors nationwide. Lyndon B. Johnson (1908-1973) was the 36th President of the United States from 1963-1969 and was John F. Kennedy's Vice President until Kennedy's assassination. Lady Bird Johnson (1912-2007) broke new ground by interacting directly with Congress and beautifying the nation's cities and highways. On March 15, 1967, President Lyndon B. Johnson and his wife Lady Bird Johnson made a day-long trip to Nashville. The Tennessee General Assembly invited Johnson to speak at a joint session to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the birth of President Andrew Jackson. Their one-day tour resulted in trips to the Hermitage, the Polk House, Ellington Agricultural Center, Columbia State Community College, and the Tennessee State Capitol.
